abstract.p: There is a growing phenomenon of evangelical NGOs engaging in ecotourism businesses. Preliminary research and case studies show that there is a diversity of approaches and methods among them, including seeing ecotourism as a method to alleviate local poverty, care for the environment and stand in solidarity with indigenous cultures. Based on this research, a theological framework is proposed to help organizations engaged in community-based ecotourism think through their endeavors in this field.

custom-meta.meta-value: 118 Caring for Creation and CultureA Survey of Evangelical Involvement in Ecotourism with a Proposed Theological Framework SAGE Publications, Inc.200910.1177/0265378809103387 Stan L.LeQuire Eastern University's School of International Leadership and Development KatieVan Gilder Eastern University's Masters of International Development program Abstract There is a growing phenomenon of evangelical NGOs engaging in ecotourism businesses. Preliminary research and case studies show that there is a diversity of approaches and methods among them, including seeing ecotourism as a method to alleviate local poverty, care for the environment and stand in solidarity with indigenous cultures. Based on this research, a theological framework is proposed to help organizations engaged in community-based ecotourism think through their endeavors in this field. community-based ecotourism creation economic development poverty theology Keywords Introduction In a global marketplace of business, industry and commerce, tourism has distin- guished itself as its largest industry. As a sector of the global economy, tourism provides both goods and services to persons or groups wishing to undertake travel for leisure or educational purposes. It employs `some 220 million people and generates over 10 per cent of the world's GDP' (World Travel and Tourism Council, 2006), is the leading growth sector of the global economy and driving economic growth in many countries (US Agency for International Development 119 Table 1: Selected Subsectors of the Global Tourism Industry [USAID], 2005),1 and is considered to have `a growth potential is unrivalled' (Tourism Industry Association of New Zealand, 2006). As summarized by the United Nations World Tourism Organization (2006), `The substantial growth of tourism activity clearly marks tourism as one of the most remarkable economic and social phenomena of the past century'. As a complex business sector, tourism contains many subsectors (see Table 1). The fastest growing subsector of this behemoth industry is ecotourism. This subsec- tor of tourism is extremely popular, more so among European tourists than North American tourists. The International Ecotourism Society (2006: 1) defines ecot- ourism as `responsible travel to natural areas that conserves the environment and improves the well-being of local people. Perhaps the reason for the global popular- ity of ecotourism is its unique combination of ethics with the goods and services of tourism. Ecotourism provides the consumer with leisure activities in a sensitive and ethical framework that uniquely addresses three key principles held dear by many consumers: environmental care, poverty alleviation and cultural solidarity. Given that ecotourism, as other industries and business as a whole, is so tied into development, it should not come as a surprise that there are evangelical develop- ment NGOs involved in this endeavor, motivated by theological frameworks engage ecotourism as a method to alleviate local poverty, to care for the environment and to stand in solidarity with indigenous cultures. In fact, evangelical ecotourism can be seen as a subset of the growing `business as mission' movement, even though there has been no attempt to analyze it as such. This article, drawing on survey research data and site visits, describes and analyzes this growing phenomenon of evangelical ecotourism businesses and proposes a theological framework to help those evangeli- cal organizations and groups engaged in community-based ecotourism, a specialized subsector of ecotourism, think through their endeavors in this field. It does so by beginning with a brief analysis of the different types of tourism and a description of the results of the survey research carried out on evangelical organiza- tions involved in community-based ecotourism, focusing on four case studies coming 120 out of that research. It then details the proposed theological framework for evangeli- cal action in this field, and concludes with suggesting some ways that the theological framework can, and should, inform the praxis of evangelical efforts in ecotourism. Poverty, Tourism, and the Specialized Subsector of Community-Based Ecotourism As stated, the global industry of tourism is a complex business sector that con- tains many subsectors. Table 1 sets out these subsectors, and their own specialized divisions. These subsectors all have one thing in common: while tourism gener- ally caters to the needs of the wealthy, it often takes place in proximity to or even within a context of poverty. The relationship between tourism and poverty is a complicated one. As is well known, poverty remains a global nemesis. Despite small, but hopeful indicators of decreases in rates (World Bank, 2008), poverty remains endemic. The World Bank states that 20 percent of the world's popula- tion continues to live on less than US$1 per day. In short, the ancient, yet modern, challenge of poverty demands new and creative approaches to its alleviation and to the generation of income for local communities. Tourism has been pointed to as one of these new and creative solutions to poverty at the macro and micro level. However, in many cases tourism flourishes precisely because local poverty allows for `reasonable' prices for wealthy tourists based on low wages and overall costs, and feeds into the (un)intentional attempts at economic development and poverty alleviation that are often simply inductions into a globalized monoculture based on materialism and consumption. Such monolithic acculturation is inherently demeaning and dangerous to ethnic groups that have survived for mil- lennia, but which, at present, are pressed from every side by the modern mono-world. While globalization appears unavoidable for humankind, there is a need for alterna- tives for minority, indigenous cultures who would reject their forced role in a global mono-world. Such alternatives must be culturally sensitive, affirming of indigenous uniqueness and preserving of human dignity, even as they afford the opportunity of open dialogues and sharing of the deeper issues of spirituality and quality of life. What better alternative than one that provides income generation and thus economic devel- opment by intentionally emphasizing the richness and dignity of the culture itself? This article posits that community-based ecotourism, a specialized subsector of ecotourism, may be such an alternative. Ecotourism services are often pro- vided in communities that are economically stressed, where the local providers can scarcely dream of the wealth owned by the tourist visitors to their villages. Community-based ecotourism is an income-generating venture in which the local community is the central stakeholder and beneficiary. The community takes own- ership of the project and receives direct economic benefit from the venture. While there may be a partnership with an outside group or business, all parties honor the involvement and ownership of the local community. Certainly, secular NGOs have embraced community-based ecotourism as a dynamic, hopeful strategy. What is less known is that community-based ecotourism has also captured the imagination and energies of some in the evangelical development community, and has the potential to grow into a much larger movement in the future. Evangelical Involvement in Ecotourism: Survey Results and Overview of Selected Projects2 In 2008, as part of the ongoing research project on ecotourism directed by Rev. Stan LeQuire at Eastern University's School of Leadership and Development (SLD), 121 a preliminary survey was conducted to discover ecotourism business ventures operated by evangelical NGOs. Due to the breadth and complexity of the evangeli- cal community, this survey can only be seen as a preliminary investigation. We sent out a total of approximately 24,900 announcements of our research plans and surveys in either electronic or print media, including email broad- cast surveys and magazine articles.3 The survey announced Eastern University's research into the evangelical engagement of ecotourism and requested basic infor- mation on ecotourism ventures operated by NGOs. Taking the survey results and combining them with ecotourism ventures already known to Eastern University,4 we identified 16 evangelical community-based ecotourism businesses. While the survey revealed only this small number of evangelical NGOs in the field of community-based ecotourism, we may have missed some and hope to continue to refine our data on this sector even as we encourage evangelical NGOs to engage community-based ecotourism to an even larger degree in the coming years. In the process of gathering information for this research project, several site vis- its were also conducted from 2003 up to the present. A variety of interviews with NGO and missions leaders reveal openness of the programmatic staff to ecotour- ism possibilities.5 Most were favorably inclined to learn more about ecotourism and to explore ventures in this sector. The dynamics of income generation and combined with local resources in various countries implied that ecotourism could be a viable, programmatic option for these NGOs. In addition, the global market for ecotourism and interest in this venture seems to be growing. For example, in 2006 a visit was made to a local university in Nicaragua that operates a thriving undergraduate program in ecotourism. During the visit, some 250 students majoring in ecotourism were conducting an ecotour- ism fair in which they enthusiastically promoted ecotourism ventures and pos- sibilities from each region in their beautiful country. Four of the 16 ventures identified by our preliminary research are briefly described. In addition, two further business are described which are provide positive examples, even if their business models do not quite fit the research defi- nition of community-based ecotourism. The purpose of these descriptions is to simply illustrate evangelical engagement of community-based ecotourism, and to provide a jumping off point for further research. MOPAWI, Honduras Moskitia Pawisa Apiska (MOPAWI) is an evangelical indigenous NGO that works in the La Mosquitia region of Honduras, Central America. This isolated area contains villages of a variety of indigenous peoples: Mosquitia, Pech, Garifuna, Tawahka, and Ladino. The region is also blessed with the Western Hemisphere's largest track of untouched rainforest north of the Amazon. MOPAWI helps protect the 815,000 hectare Río Plátano Biosphere Reserve, which comprises a large por- tion of the rainforest. As a development organization, MOPAWI operates many projects, such as substance abuse education, youth programs, and a vibrant com- munity-based ecotourism project which is located within the biosphere reserve. The Ecotourism Committee of Las Marías, one of the principal villages within the reserve, organizes most of the ecotourist visits to the reserve. Local villagers offer food, lodging and tours on a rotational basis as organized by the local committee. In addition, the committee trains villagers to serve as certified tour guides who are knowledgeable in the local flora and fauna. Due to MOPAWI's impressive efforts and results, this community-based eco- tourism venture has garnered extensive, international attention. Conservation 122 organizations and many researchers have partnered with and studied MOPAWI. Furthermore, a wide variety of different NGOs cooperate to promote the role of ecotourism in the Río Plátano Biosphere Reserve. These include RARE Conservation, La Ruta Moskitia, MOPAWI itself and even the United Nations. Proyecto Aldea Global, Honduras Proyecto Aldea Global (PAG), an evangelical nongovernmental organization, operates a variety of significant projects in Honduras, including ones dealing with sustainable agriculture and water resource management. In addition, PAG co-manages the Cerro Azul Meambar National Park (PANACAM) in a Honduran cloud forest,6 and within this Park it operates a thriving community-based ecot- ourism business. Two key components of its ecotourism outreach include a restau- rant and nature interpretation center, La Naturaleza Visitor Center, on the shores of Yojoa Lake and an ecotourism lodge and environmental education center in the village of Los Pinos. PAG uses paid and volunteer staff from local indigenous Lenca villages to carry out its ministries of creation care and poverty alleviation. Annual visitors number in the thousands and are mostly Hondurans who take advantage of the glorious scenery and the lodging facilities for retreats and vaca- tions. The government of Honduras has awarded PAG with national honors for its outstanding ecotourism ventures. Bushara Island Camp, Uganda Bushara Island Camp is located on the shores of Lake Bunyonyi, in the Kabale dis- trict of Uganda. The project started through a partnership with Anglican Church of Uganda, Diocese of Kigezi, the Africa Community Technical Service (ACTS), and the Lake Bunyonyi community. The camp offers guests a variety of lodging options from pitching one's own tent to fully furnished rooms. An on-site restau- rant serves delicious meals. The Camp takes advantage of its beautiful setting and the richness of local life with natural and cultural tours. All profits from the Camp go to local community projects including agro-forestry, small livestock distribu- tion, orphan care, HIV/AIDS education, and other income generation projects. Pacaya Tours, Nicaragua This is one of the simplest ecotourism projects discovered by our research. Pacaya Tours consists of a hiking trail around a scenic lake 35 kilometers south of Managua, the capital of Nicaragua. This tourism business is operated by a local community development organization and supported by World Vision Nicaragua. The hikes provide scenic views of lake, tropical forest, and smoldering volcanoes. This ecotourism business, along with its restaurant services and souvenir sales, generates income for the local Nicaraguans. Two Additional Businesses In addition, there are several, stellar ecotourism projects operated by evangelical NGOs or business persons, but which do not technically meet the research defi- nition of community-based ecotourism. Two such businesses, Latigo Ranch and Kuzuko Lodge, are now described. Latigo Ranch, USA Award-winning Latigo Ranch is a `dude ranch' that fits the North American tra- dition, but not the stereotype. Complete with horses and wranglers (`cowboys'), a holiday at the ranch is like a trip back in time. Nestled up against the Arapaho 123 National Forest, this five-star resort boasts spectacular scenery, comfortable mountain cabins with a pot-bellied wood stoves, `nouvelle ranch cuisine', and delightful staff including knowledgeable (and patient) wranglers. While some may think that horses and their care are antithetical to a healthy environment, Latigo Ranch operates out of an exemplary environmental ethic. The staff maintains proactive relationships with the United States Forest Service and models creation care techniques. For example, Latigo has pioneered a new method of corralling horses during overnight camping trips with his guests. Previously, the standard was the use of a high line tether or remuda line. Latigo uses portable, bat- tery-operated electric fencing and a new corral site with each trip. Then, as camp is broken the wranglers spread the horse waste so that it does not collect in unsightly piles or release concentrated toxins. Corralling thus reduces impact on fragile alpine ecosystems and eliminates siltation along stream beds. After initial skepticism, the Forest Service gave up tethering and now prefers Latigo's method of overnight cor- ralling. The Latigo staff keep abreast of the latest ecological principles in horse care, forest management and pasture care. They believe that horse touring combined with a strong ethic of creation care is better than some of the more modern forms of recreational touring, such as mountain biking (LeQuire, 2007). Kuzuko, South Africa Kuzuko Lodge is located on a hilltop overlooking an extremely remote, but beau- tiful, corner of South Africa. Lodging and facilities are on a par with any five-star resort and includes 24 bungalows, a restaurant, pool, spa and complete confer- ence facilities. Besides comfort and rest, other activities include game drives, hik- ing to view ancient bushman cave paintings and bird-watching. The 14,500 hec- tares administered by Kuzuko are a private concession within the Addo Elephant National Park. Through a unique partnership with the South African national park system, Kuzuko is reintroducing native fauna and rehabilitating the unique regional flora. Archbishop Emeritus and Nobel Peace Prize winner Desmond Tutu officially opened Kuzuko on 3 November 2008. In his remarks, he expressed gratitude for Kuzuko's vision of alleviating poverty in the Eastern Cape province and said: `Thank you for believing in our people and contributing towards their upliftment. This country is a scintillating success waiting to happen and projects like this one ensure that our people have the opportunity to realize their potential' (Legacy Hotels and Resorts International, 2008). Kuzuko was founded by a consortium of Christian business persons and venture capitalists dedicated to social transforma- tion in the Eastern Cape province, where unemployment and HIV/AIDS rates are unusually high. The goal is to operate a tourism business that is both ecologically sustainable and involved in the local community through a variety of outreach programs .7 Another unique partnership links Kuzuko with Umziwethu, a South African development organization, which provides job training and placement for South Africans from disadvantaged backgrounds. Kuzuko has hired chefs, waiters and trained field guides from Umziwethu. A Proposed Theological Framework The research undertaken reveals an initial picture of what evangelical NGOs are doing in the area of community-based ecotourism. Additional research needs to be undertaken as to why they are engaging such a unique business venture and how they are doing it. Are they engaging in it because of its increasing global 124 popularity? Is it because their faith and theology compel them to engage such a potentially holistic option? Are they integrating a holistic gospel message into their efforts, including sharing the message of salvation? These and other ques- tions mirror, not surprisingly, the questions that are also asked of the business as mission movement, of which evangelical ecotourism can be seen as a very intrigu- ing, and informative, subset. This article proposes a preliminary theological framework for evangelical involvement in community-based ecotourism as a jumping off point for further research and dialogue about praxis with evangelical NGOs who currently engage community-based ecotourism. In addition, such a framework could go a long way in supporting new endeavors in community-based ecotourism. This theological framework posits that community-based ecotourism is a dynamic venture where creation, culture and economic betterment meet. It takes these three concepts as its starting points and suggests that these three components are best addressed within a narrative, missiological theology. It is to that narrative that we first turn. A Comprehensive Narrative Missiological Theology The narrative theological framework presupposes that a divine metanarrative, God's story, is operative in creation and in culture. Briefly stated, this metanarrative begins with the `genesis' of creation and culture and concludes with its redemp- tion and thus fulfillment in a `new heaven and a new earth'. Creation and culture are major players or actors in this metanarrative. Unfortunately, creation and culture are often seen as minor sideshows, inferior subplots, or simply props by humankind, another major actor in this metanarrative. Narrative theology can encourage a re-evaluation of all actors in God's story. Narrative theology thrives in context and will ask questions of its context. South African theologian Ernst Conradie frames the major, contextual questions as `“Who is God?” … “What is God doing today?” [and] “What is God doing in our own lives and the life of this (extended) family, this community, this congre- gation, this country and this bioregion?”' (Conradie, 2005). Conradie's questions are similar to those someone would ask of a novel or movie. What is happening in this story? Narrative theology engages reflection on these kinds of questions. As stated, narrative theology describes creation and culture as major players or actors in the divine metanarrative. Creation and culture are also key components of community-based ecotourism. Humans can interact with culture and creation within the context of community-based ecotourism. This subsector of tourism is a promising vehicle for participating in the acts of God within specific contexts of culture and creation. For the evangelical development worker, narrative theology helps ask significant questions, such as, `What is God doing in our rainforest or desert and how can we participate in these acts? If God has created human cul- tures, how does our unique culture fit in with God's metanarrative?'. Such ques- tions provide vital reflection and motivation to sustain a vibrant outreach in the area of community-based ecotourism. Theology of Creation Any group that establishes and operates a community-based ecotourism venture, engages creation and attempts to care for creation in a unique way. Some values or beliefs will be operative in the business. These might be ethical or environmen- tal or a combination of both. What about evangelical NGOs? Does a theology of creation inform their business venture? While it is unknown now whether or not 125 such groups make use of a theology of creation, such a theology is vital in and what follows we briefly introduce the lines it might follow. Creation is the beginning and foundational act in God's metanarrative. Created reality is the framework or the physical stage for all our development activities. Creation's capacity to provide us with sustenance testifies to God's goodness and majesty. The created world is the recipient of God's redemptive acts, and the witness in God's judgment of the human response to this world. Of course, on a practical level, any ecotourism venture will not succeed without creation. The most significant part of creation is the imago Dei, the human creature. Out of a robust theology of creation arises the understanding that humans have the privilege of participating in the care of creation.8 Currently, one of the more popular ways of engaging creation in this `care-ful' way is through ecotourism. Community-based ecotourism models a hopeful approach to interacting with creation. The vision here is for evangelical operators of an ecotourism venture to embrace their locale as a gift and trust from the Creator. They would understand the privi- lege of welcoming visitors as a calling to help the visitors enjoy what God has made and learn of God's ways in creation. Community owners of the venture would express their theology of creation in large and small actions – from land preservation and stewardship all the way to the disposal of trash from guest rooms. While many of the customers of the ecotourism business may not express interest in the theological underpinnings, at least the staff would own and act on their beliefs. The leaders of the ecotourism project would assure that all staff per- sons are trained to understand a vital theology of creation, as well as a theology of culture, which is our next topic. Theology of Culture For good or for ill, humans engage culture (and creation) constantly. A theology of culture is closely related to a theology of creation, because humans engage creation using their culture. Within the biblical creation narrative comes a crucial scene: the creation of humans and their call to respond to creation in cultural ways. Scholars often refer to this establishment of culture as the `cultural man- date'. While a theology of creation provides a framework for relating to all created reality, a theology of culture addresses issues that are uniquely anthropocentric. Beyond the origin and establishment of culture is the role of human cultures in the narrative and activity of God's redemption. A theology of culture holds that all human cultures will be redeemed and exist throughout eternity. Such an exalted role for human cultures implies two things. First, that the loss of cultures, especially the vast wealth of indigenous cultures, is not written into God's metan- arrative, and is therefore evil. Thus, if globalization contributes to the extinction of human cultures, then globalization must be confronted by the people of God. Second, missional groups must understand that a part of the missio Dei is at least the protection of human culture, if not preservation of all that is good within human culture. It is at this point that human and indigenous rights can enter the discussion. The redemption of human cultures can be supported in the present by human and indigenous rights advocacy, and it can easily be seen as integral to missional commitment in that such advocacy is supported by an understanding of God's metanarrative. In a context where community-based ecotourism is engaged out of a missional commitment, it is important that the stakeholders think theologically about cul- ture. They will need to reflect on the value and worth of their culture and their reasons for sharing their culture with their customers. Hopefully, in their theology 126 they will find a rich resource and anchor for the cultural aspects of their ecotour- ism business. Ancient scriptural teachings on the value, worth and dignity of human culture are compelling, yet largely ignored or misunderstood. In short, Revelation 7:9 envisions all cultures as redeemed by God and gathered in praise around his throne for eternity. It is therefore incumbent that Christians among all people should be intentional and dedicated to the preservation of all that is good within their culture and in the plethora of global cultures. Due to their zeal and the global reach of their work, evangelicals are positioned to make a great contribution to cultural solidarity. It would appear that communi- ty-based ecotourism is a timely idea that could provide an incentive and a matrix for evangelical action on behalf of indigenous cultures. Before this can happen, evangelicals must either develop a theology of creation and culture or at least popularize and disseminate one that already exists.9 Unfortunately however, evangelical missional groups have often been criticized as insensitive to the value and worth of the planet's indigenous cultures.1 0 On a more practical level, while natural beauty is a key component of a success- ful ecotourism business, the same is true of cultural beauty. Local cultures and eco- tourism make easy and welcome partners. It is common for ecotourism business ventures to incorporate cultural elements into the business model. Cuisine for the tourists and activities for their leisure are often centered upon the host culture and shared with pride and enthusiasm. In summary, when an evangelical NGO engages ecotourism, will the cultur- al components and activities of their business be supported by their theology? Do evangelical entrepreneurs respond theologically to these and other culturally- related issues? Do their staff and does the community understand theological ram- ifications of their business venture? These are questions that a theological frame- work for evangelical ecotourism should encourage the NGOs to reflect upon. Theology of Poverty Practitioners of development must reflect theologically on poverty, as they do on all dynamics within God's story. Poverty is closely related to creation and culture, because it is a condition that results from a relational pattern of humans with creation and culture. This relational pattern or approach is based on power and its manipulation.1 1 When humans misuse power to respond to creation, domination can result. When humans misuse power to relate to other cultures, the result is the domination of powerful cultures over less-powerful cultures, as well as racism, and poverty. Any theology of poverty must address issues of power. Dealing with issues of power is vital to participating with God in mission. Those who possess power face serious challenges that could easily compromise the mission and must take seri- ously that observation that `authentic development [can] not take place without the transfer of power' (Bosch, 1991: 357).1 2 Power relates integrally to communi- ty-based ecotourism. Community-based ecotourism allows for the empowerment of communities, if not the transfer of power itself. As community developers and leaders begin to consider community-based ecotourism, the community takes stock of its natural and cultural assets, as well as its need for income diversifica- tion. Then, the community decides to establish an ecotourism venture as a pos- sible response to these local dynamics and realities. Ecotourism is a viable and attractive response that carries the potential to keep resources and power within the local communities. The community discovers its wealth and the capital of the community and locale and takes ownership of it. 127 Potential for Theological Discourse and Praxis Community-based ecotourism provides a fertile context for dialogue and practice around key theological and missiological concepts. What follows are some brief comments about how community-based ecotourism can contribute to theological discussions and the effective practice of theology. Despite the fact that environmental issues garner global concern, evangelicals lag behind in environmental engagement and remediation. Nonetheless, issues of creation's care are being rediscovered by the evangelical community. In part, the rediscovery can is documented by the theological surveys of Dyrness (1997) and Bouma-Prediger (2001). This renewed interest in theologies of creation has even generated a few popular titles.1 3 However, the development of evangelical, theological reflection and praxis in this area needs to continue. Ecotourism has the potential to take theology beyond the printed page and into an outdoor labora- tory. It takes little imagination to see that ecotourism has great pedagogical and economic benefits. In an ecotourism context, tourists/customers can learn how local Christians think theologically about their land and their culture. Community-based ecotourism can serve as an outpost of hope in a world thirsty for economic, environmental, and spiritual options. Ecotourism combines environmental sustainability, income generation and solidarity with indigenous cultures to yield a rich, viable option for community development. The participa- tion of missional groups in ecotourism can further promote these benefits while adding a deeper theological and spiritual meaning. For example, through ecotour- ism Christians could provide witness to the eschatological hope for the redemp- tion of both creation and human culture, sharing the truth about the saving power of Christ as part and parcel of the process. Ecotourism, in summary, can point the world to the `new heaven and new earth' and begin the celebration of all peoples, tribes and nations around the throne (Revelations 7:9, 21:1). With respect to cultural dynamics, many missional groups continue to struggle with the anthropological reality of human culture, and the theological concepts, such as the goodness of culture and the `cultural mandate'. Far too often, missional groups relate to culture as an impediment rather than an opportunity or as a curse rather than a God-given blessing. Community-based ecotourism has the potential to show missional groups the power and beauty of human culture. In fact, ecotour- ism interfaces seamlessly with cultural solidarity, if not even cultural preservation. Finally, community-based ecotourism has the potential to provide additional reflection on theology as it leads to action. For too long, mission endeavors have been practiced as an invasive procedure from a culture of power or dominant culture into a supposedly weaker culture. Unfortunately, these traditional models of mission have ignored the fact that these so-called `weaker cultures' have much to offer, and the so-called dominant cultures have much to learn. Ecotourism is a promising matrix where `missions in reverse' could take place. In this refreshing paradigm, mission groups enter local communities with respect and humility. They leave having learned from indigenous cultures. In this way, intercultural dialogue and `intercultural learning' (Shenk, 2003) are encouraged, even in a relaxed and informal way. Such learning and dialogue are vitally needed in today's world. Conclusion In creation and in culture, God is daily accomplishing mighty acts. Using a theo- logical framework, human interaction with creation and culture is best viewed as 128 a partnership with God in the world. Thus, groups engaging community-based ecotourism as missional commitment can ask, as Verstraelen does, what is God doing in creation and in human culture? What is the nature of `the dynamic rela- tionship between God and the world [where] God sends himself, his Son and his church?' (Verstraelen, 1995: 4). These narrative-type questions demonstrate the many linkages between narrative theologies of poverty, creation, and cul- ture. Indeed, community-based ecotourism provides a rich and rewarding matrix for theology, mission, and development. Community-based ecotourism makes our theologizing and our development ministries a compelling and captivating enterprise. Community-based ecotourism, when engaged by evangelical NGOs, should be carried out in a way that is prophetic and redemptive, and thereby `mir- rors' God back to his created world.1 4 Community-based ecotourism can be seen as an authentically human endeavor, as a signpost of what God can accomplish redemptively through the people of God who are active in creation and culture.
